history.content:
<md>It should be fine although your experience will improve a lot if you take EE 127 before or concurrently. I would also recommend upper-division probability (STAT 134/140/EE 126). However, the official prereqs are only:
*   Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),
*   Math 54, Math 110, or EE 16A+16B (or another linear algebra course),
*   CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
*   Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)

IMO you should be fine without 53 and EE 126 as long as you do a bit of self-studying of probability concepts beforehand that were not covered in CS 70. DATA 100 should help a bit too!</md>

<md>It should be fine although your experience will improve a lot if you take EE 127 concurrently. I would also recommend upper-division probability (STAT 134/140/EE 126). However, the official prereqs are only:
*   Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),

*   CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
*   Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)

IMO you should be fine without 53 and EE 126 as long as you do a bit of self-studying of probability concepts beforehand that were not covered in CS 70. DATA 100 should help a bit too!</md>

*   Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),
*   Math 54, Math 110, or EE 16A+16B (or another linear algebra course),
*   CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
*   Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)

IMO you should be fine without 53 and EE 126 as long as you do a bit of self-studying of probability concepts beforehand that were not covered in CS 70.</md>

<md>It should be fine although your experience will improve a lot if you take EE 127 concurrently. I would also recommend upper-division probability (STAT 134/140/EE 126). However, the official prereqs are only:
*   Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),
*   Math 54, Math 110, or EE 16A+16B (or another linear algebra course),
*   CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
*   Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)

IMO you should be fine without 53 and without EE 126 as long as you do a bit of self-studying of probability concepts beforehand that were not covered in CS 70.</md>

children.subject: with shewchuk much of the math is applied so the concepts involving probability are a bit more intuitive than raw probability like in stat 134, imo. i would recommend at least studying up on the probability concepts in cs70, but i do not think taking a dedicated probability course is necessary. shewchuk’s hw2 is all math and basically covers any math concepts you will need in the class, so while the hw is hard it is good study material to make sure you’re ready for the class. anything not covered in hw2 (and some concepts which are covered in hw2) will be taught later in the course, so you are not expected to be a genius expert in probability or any of the other math used in the class, just familiar enough to understand what he is talking about when he teaches.

history.content: I want to take 189 Spring 2022. Can I get away with not taking any upper div probability course and eecs 127? For reference I have taking all the required lower divs for CS + ds100
history.subject: Question regarding Cs 189 Spring iteration
